Models

The models package contains data structures that represent the core entities in the BusFlow system. All models follow Python naming conventions with PascalCase for class names.

User Model

User model for the BusFlow application.

This module defines the User class that represents all types of users in the system: passengers (USER), drivers (DRIVER), and administrators (ADMIN).

module:

app.models.user

class app.models.user.User(user_id, email, name, role)[source]

Bases: UserMixin

Represents a user in the BusFlow system.

Users can have one of three roles: - USER: Regular passengers who book tickets - DRIVER: Bus drivers who view their assignments - ADMIN: Administrators who manage the fleet

Parameters:

  • user_id (str) – Unique identifier for the user (UUID from Supabase)

  • email (str) – User’s email address for authentication

  • name (str) – User’s display name

  • role (str) – User’s role (USER, DRIVER, or ADMIN)

Example:

user = User(
    user_id='uuid-123',
    email='user@example.com',
    name='John Doe',
    role='USER'
)
__init__(user_id, email, name, role)[source]

Initialize a new User instance.

Parameters:

  • user_id (str) – Unique identifier for the user

  • email (str) – User’s email address

  • name (str) – User’s display name

  • role (str) – User’s role in the system

Bus Model

Bus model for the BusFlow application.

This module defines the Bus class that represents buses in the fleet, including their routes, capacity, and operational status.

module:

app.models.bus

class app.models.bus.Bus(bus_id, name, route, total_seats=40, driver_id=None, price=50, status='ACTIVE')[source]

Bases: object

Represents a bus in the BusFlow fleet.

Each bus has a defined route (sequence of stops), seat capacity, optional driver assignment, ticket price, and operational status.

Parameters:

  • bus_id (str) – Unique identifier for the bus (UUID)

  • name (str) – Display name of the bus (e.g., “Dhaka Chaka 01”)

  • route (list) – Ordered list of bus stops defining the route

  • total_seats (int) – Total number of seats available

  • driver_id (str or None) – UUID of assigned driver or None

  • price (int) – Ticket price in BDT

  • status (str) – Operational status (ACTIVE, MAINTENANCE, DECOMMISSIONED)

Example:

bus = Bus(
    bus_id='uuid-456',
    name='Red Express 01',
    route=['Uttara', 'Banani', 'Farmgate'],
    total_seats=40,
    driver_id=None,
    price=50,
    status='ACTIVE'
)
__init__(bus_id, name, route, total_seats=40, driver_id=None, price=50, status='ACTIVE')[source]

Initialize a new Bus instance.

Parameters:

  • bus_id (str) – Unique identifier for the bus

  • name (str) – Display name of the bus

  • route (list) – List of stops in order

  • total_seats (int) – Seat capacity

  • driver_id (str or None) – Assigned driver’s ID

  • price (int) – Ticket price in BDT

  • status (str) – Bus operational status

Get the number of stops in the route.

Returns:

Number of stops

Return type:

is_valid_trip(source, destination)[source]

Check if a trip from source to destination is valid on this route.

A trip is valid if both source and destination exist on the route and source comes before destination.

Parameters:

  • source (str) – Name of the boarding stop

  • destination (str) – Name of the destination stop

Returns:

True if the trip is valid

Return type:

bool

Booking Model

Booking model for the BusFlow application.

This module defines the Booking class that represents ticket bookings made by passengers for specific bus journeys.

module:

app.models.booking

class app.models.booking.Booking(booking_id, user_id, bus_id, seat_number, source, destination, booking_date, price, status='CONFIRMED', created_at=None)[source]

Bases: object

Represents a ticket booking in the BusFlow system.

A booking captures all details about a passenger’s reserved seat on a specific bus for a particular journey.

Parameters:

  • booking_id (str) – Unique identifier for the booking (UUID)

  • user_id (str) – ID of the user who made the booking

  • bus_id (str) – ID of the booked bus

  • seat_number (str) – Seat label (e.g., “A1”, “B3”)

  • source (str) – Name of the boarding stop

  • destination (str) – Name of the destination stop

  • booking_date (str) – Date of the journey

  • price (int) – Price paid for the ticket in BDT

  • status (str) – Booking status (CONFIRMED or CANCELLED)

  • created_at (str) – Timestamp when booking was created

Example:

booking = Booking(
    booking_id='uuid-789',
    user_id='user-123',
    bus_id='bus-456',
    seat_number='A1',
    source='Uttara',
    destination='Motijheel',
    booking_date='2024-12-15',
    price=50,
    status='CONFIRMED'
)
__init__(booking_id, user_id, bus_id, seat_number, source, destination, booking_date, price, status='CONFIRMED', created_at=None)[source]

Initialize a new Booking instance.

Parameters:

  • booking_id (str) – Unique identifier for the booking

  • user_id (str) – ID of the booking user

  • bus_id (str) – ID of the booked bus

  • seat_number (str) – Reserved seat label

  • source (str) – Boarding stop name

  • destination (str) – Destination stop name

  • booking_date (str) – Journey date

  • price (int) – Ticket price

  • status (str) – Booking status

  • created_at (str) – Creation timestamp

Returns:
